qa_pairs.question: What is the significance of the exchange rate mentioned in Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 243, and which parties were involved in the mortgage transaction described in the document?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The exchange rate mentioned in Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 243 is significant because it explicitly states the ratio between copper drachmae and silver drachmae as 1800 to 4, providing historical insight into the monetary system of the time.<cite>[S13]</cite></statement> <statement>The mortgage transaction described in the document involved Didymus, who issued the mortgage, and Dionysius, who received it, with the agreement involving 1,300 silver drachmae and real property as security.<cite>[S12]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 243


# Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 243



**Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 243** (**P. [S2] Oxy. [S3] 243** or **P. [S4] Oxy. [S5] II 243**) is a fragment containing a registration of a mortgage, written in Greek. [S6] It was discovered in Oxyrhynchus. [S7] The manuscript was written on papyrus in the form of a sheet. [S8] It is dated between 25 February and 24 March 79. [S9] Currently it is housed in the British Library (Department of Manuscripts, 790) in London. [S10] ## Description

The document was written by Chairemon, son of Chairemon, and was addressed to the agoranymus. [S11] It describes a mortgage issued by Didymus to Dionysius of 1,300 silver drachmae with some real property as security for a term of one year at an interest rate of one percent per month. [S12] The most interesting aspect of the document historically is that it states explicitly that the rate of exchange between copper drachmae and silver was, at the time, 1800 to 4. [S13] The measurements of the fragment are 235 by 112 mm. [S14] It was discovered by Grenfell and Hunt in 1897 in Oxyrhynchus. [S15] The text was published by Grenfell and Hunt in 1899.
